newsitem.title: GERMANY: German shares solid ahead of May 1 holiday.
newsitem.headline: German shares solid ahead of May 1 holiday.

text.p: German shares proved resilient to U.S. shocks on Wednesday, posting solid gains in the bourse session and recovering fast from a brief dip on stronger-than-expected U.S. data in the post-bourse session.

The IBIS DAX index ended the day up 12.23 points at 3,438.09 points, having briefly dropped to a low of 3,416.11 points after a far stronger than expected first quarter U.S. GDP report retriggered concern about imminent rate rises.
"The market seems to be holding up well against shocks from the U.S. at the moment," said one dealer. "I think the 3,400 (DAX points) level is pretty well secured."
The DAX index, catching up with gains made in post-bourse dealings on Tuesday, had ended the bourse session at mid-afternoon at 3,438.07, up 54.88 points.
Volumes were generally low ahead of the May 1 public holiday which will keep the market closed on Thursday.
"People are just establishing themselves in reasonably safe waters. There is always the fear that there will be major developments while we are closed," a Munich dealer said.
Chemical giant Bayer AG, trading ex-dividend, fell 2.96 marks, or four percent at 67.24 marks in IBIS trade.
Drugs group Schering AG gained 2.55 marks to 165.50 marks over the day, boosted after revealing plans to buy back its own shares once this is legally feasible.
Electronics and engineering giant Siemens AG continued its recent run of popularity, fuelled by technical buy signals and analyst recommendations, to rise 76 pfennigs to 93.81 marks.
Some dealers were optimistic that the market was well positioned to break out of its current lethargy next week.
More dividend payments are expected in the coming weeks, which should boost liquidity as investors reinvest the payouts.
